{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3681243,"name":"Kegan Cherry","username":"kegancherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T18:46:22.826Z","cooked":"

A big concept ive ran into during my first year of FRC programming is about the two main ways teams seem to approach tuning subsystems, especially when it comes to things like feedforward values for elevators, arms, drivetrains, etc.

One option is to just try different values until something works. The other is to break out the physics and calculate everything based on known specs. Both work, but they each come with tradeoffs.

The Empirical Route

This is the trial-and-error approach you give the mechanism some voltage, see what holds it in place or gets it moving, and record that as your constant. It’s fast, intuitive, and based on what actually happens on the robot.

Some examples:

  • Manually tuning kG by finding the voltage that holds an elevator in place
  • Running test paths to tune kS, kV, kA
  • Adjusting PID gains by feel or through testing

It works well when you’re short on time or don’t have all your numbers nailed down, but it can take longer to retune if you change something like a gear ratio, motor, or weight.

The Calculated Route

This is where you model the system on paper before you even power it on. You figure out the force needed to counter gravity, convert that to motor torque, then voltage using motor specs. Ideally, you end up with constants that are close to correct from the start.

Some tools that help here:

  • CAD mass properties
  • Motor curves (from the REV/CTRE data sheets)
  • Gear ratios and mechanism geometry
  • FRC Characterization (sysid)

This method can scale better as your design changes, and it helps new students learn the “why” behind the numbers. But if your model is off wrong mass, underestimated friction; the results can be pretty far from what you actually need.

What I’m Wondering

Curious what other teams do here. A few questions to kick things off:

  • Do you start with calculations or go straight to testing on the robot?
  • How much do you rely on modeling vs. trial and error?
  • Do you recalculate your constants every time the design changes?
  • How well do your calculated constants usually match what ends up working?
  • Have you changed your approach over time as your team got more experience?
  • How do you help new students understand both sides of this?

Would love to hear what’s worked for you whether you mostly test things out on the robot or try to get close with math first.

Teams may reconsider what they choose when more tools come out to support theoretical tuning and they get more experience with it.

Yeah, I tried to use Recalc for tuning my elevator PID constants, however there seems to be a loss in all the variables that go into mechanical applications. To me it seems like there would have to be thousands of variables for these kind of tools to be truly accurate.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:01:31.952Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":210,"readers_count":209,"score":57.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kegan Cherry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.reca.lc/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681257,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:06:56.668Z","cooked":"

Most of what we’ve done this year was using calculated constants (via recalc) to get ballpark estimates but then using hand tuning to get more of the behavior that we want from the system. This season, nearly all of our tuning constants were adjusted manually at some point by the end of the season. We’ve used sysid on drive motors and that’s worked well however we’ve seen better results through manual tuning when it comes to steer motors.

There fortunately isn’t. I am working on a way to allow you to sim and test theoreticals on a webpage, based off wpilib sim in docs.wpilib.org and link to reca.lc with a filled out inputs based on a webform made to generate code for subsystems.

Do y’all use sysid for more than just drivetrains? Ive always thought of system characterization as the best way to tune constants but have never seen it implemented in things like arms or elevators.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:21:25.428Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":42.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kegan Cherry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":65568,"username":"therekrab","name":"Nolan Barker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681264,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:22:19.608Z","cooked":"

No, just for the drivetrain.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:22:19.608Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":50.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Nolan Barker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"reply_to_user":{"id":73648,"username":"kegancherry","name":"Kegan Cherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead - 3414 Hackbots"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/8","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681266,"name":"Kegan Cherry","username":"kegancherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:27:36.598Z","cooked":"

That’s sounds wonderful. I like the idea of being able to integrate everything rather than having 50 different tools. It would be neat (albeit extremely tedious) to have a software that used cad models to simulate this kind of thing so the entire mechanism could be tested. It could even be used for stress analysis.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:27:36.598Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":35.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kegan Cherry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681267,"name":"Lauchlin","username":"Nessie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nessie/{size}/9356_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:27:37.558Z","cooked":"

Depends on the system really. But using math to pick a good starting point for numbers and then tuning empirically from there is a good approach.

It’s fairly common to be retuning these robots all season long as they wear in or are modified. (Physically or in code)

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-15T12:30:04.448Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":170,"readers_count":169,"score":94.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Lauchlin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29278,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681268,"name":"Kegan Cherry","username":"kegancherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:31:03.572Z","cooked":"

This is what im seeing from many teams. Previously when i was first tuning our 2025 robot, Nessie, I used .0005, continuously multiplied by 10 until i got feedback. Then of course tune to correct feedback but next year I’ll give recalc a thought.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:31:03.572Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":161,"readers_count":160,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kegan Cherry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":29278,"username":"Nessie","name":"Lauchlin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nessie/{size}/9356_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681273,"name":"Kabir","username":"kn4","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kn4/{size}/235296_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:39:56.683Z","cooked":"
kegancherry:
  • FRC Characterization (sysid)

SysId kinda fits in both categories: you can use the characterization tool for empirical tuning and there’s also the feedback analysis part which finds the optimal gains.

I think kV is usually fine to calculate via gear ratios unless you have a mechanism that could have a lot of viscous friction, like a flywheel.

I don’t really know how you would calculate kS though and it’s pretty easy to empirically estimate it.

I don’t think calculating kG is that useful either, since it’s also easy to estimate. (For something like an elevator, find the highest and lowest voltage outputs that hold up the elevator with no motion; the average is kG and the range divided by two is kS.) But it can be useful to use recalc’s estimated kG to get an approximate range.

For elevators, kA is just kG divided by gravity (Edit: Actually, after thinking about this more, this might be incorrect?), so you can use that (converting units where necessary). kA usually doesn’t make that big of a difference so I think it’s fine to calculate it based on recalc.

In terms of feedback control, I sometimes use the sysid feedback analyzer to get a ballpark estimate of what the P/D gains should be, and the approach of “increase P until oscillation starts, increase D until oscillation stops, repeat if necessary” is also useful as well.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T21:17:10.676Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":155,"readers_count":154,"score":66.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kabir","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57470,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2724 programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/12","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681274,"name":"Kegan Cherry","username":"kegancherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:45:25.623Z","cooked":"

How important in your opinion is it to tune all of these? This year i used position voltage on our elevator with only p & d, which worked pretty well and snappy for what i needed. Do you think that the time you would put into tuning these is worth how much time and reduction in wear you gain?

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:45:25.623Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kegan Cherry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":57470,"username":"kn4","name":"Kabir","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kn4/{size}/235296_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/13","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681275,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:49:02.704Z","cooked":"

I support calculating your constants whenever possible as when done correctly, you can dune your mechanisms very quickly and maximize the performance out of them.

kegancherry:

Do you start with calculations or go straight to testing on the robot?

The absolute best thing about designing controllers by math/simulation is that you can design them and understand the system behavior before you even have a robot, and use those results to influence the robot design. The other benefits are nice and I use simulations before, during, and after building the robot, but the ability for it to influence your design decisions is the most important benefit by a lot.

kegancherry:

Do you recalculate your constants every time the design changes?

If the mass significantly changes, you will usually have to re-tune for the new system inertia and re-tune the feedback gains. The rest of the system properties should stay the same however.

kegancherry:

Some tools that help here:

  • CAD mass properties
  • Motor curves (from the REV/CTRE data sheets)
  • Gear ratios and mechanism geometry
  • FRC Characterization (sysid)

Do note that FRC motor vendors do not provide the motor inertia, which is often very significant if not the dominant dynamics of the system due to inertia scaling from gear reductions. Until FRC vendors start providing better data, sysID of some form is required to properly identify the system inertia. They also don’t provide very good motor data, which can hinder modeling accuracy.

kV should always be calculated as it is overwhelmingly influenced by the motor’s back-emf. While kA can be calculated using J/(kt*ratio), it (or really the system inertia) must be obtained through sysID because the motor inertia need to be accounted for as it can range from very significant to overwhelmingly dominant in terms of system dynamics.

Feedback gains however should be tuned in simulation or the robot. While there are techniques to calculate when with math, the math relies on idealized models that don’t work in the not so pretty world. So you either have to simulate the not-so-pretty world (doable) or tune on the physical robot.

One more very important thing is that feedback and feedforward constants have both units and a frame of reference and you need to know what these are when mathing them out. kP of 1000 is unhelpful because 10000 whats? s^-1? A-s/rad? V-min/rot?

kegancherry:

But if your model is off wrong mass, underestimated friction; the results can be pretty far from what you actually need.

Unless you are trying to gain the last few ms of performance out of a mechanism or are working with complicated mechanisms such as a double-jointed arm, the model doesn’t need to be 100% perfect to have good performace due to feedback.

kegancherry:

Yeah, I tried to use Recalc for tuning my elevator PID constants, however there seems to be a loss in all the variables that go into mechanical applications. To me it seems like there would have to be thousands of variables for these kind of tools to be truly accurate.

Recalc’s sim is not good due to not simulating deceleration which is extremely important. AMB will find the ratio better due to simulating decel, but a custom simulation will get you much better results because you can make sure you simulate all relevant dynamics. These tools also don’t work if the robot is mechanically bad (very poor stiffness, backlash, non-constant friction…) or is non-linear (linkages are the big offender mainly), do designing mechanisms that are stiff and do what they are told should be the highest priority.

I’ve found you only need 9 constants to have your sim accurately simulate reality reality. You need

  • Inertia
  • Visocus damping
  • Dry friction
  • Extenral forces
  • Motor effective armature resistance
  • Back-emf constant
  • Torque constant (its not quite equal to the back-emf constant in the real world)
  • Pure time delay
  • Sampling frequency

The last two are extremely important when simulating controllers as they are typically the reason controllers go unstable and severely limit the amount of derivative gain you can apply and can make you prefer a slightly lower ratio than would be optimal in a perfect world.

therekrab:

We’ve used sysid on drive motors and that’s worked well however we’ve seen better results through manual tuning when it comes to steer motors.

Swerve is annoying because the friction is both super non-linear and just difficult (practically impossible) to model, which is very significant on the steering motors. I wouldn’t ever reccomending using sims or math on these types of mechanisms as its not designed to handle these types of non-linearities.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:49:02.704Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":3,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":79.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/14","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681278,"name":"Justin Tervay","username":"jtrv","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jtrv/{size}/203436_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:56:20.015Z","cooked":"

Author of Recalc here. I don’t actually use any of the gains feature on the site, although they’re useful for others.

My teams have historically simply empirically tuned everything. Doesn’t take very long once you do it a few times. If we lose a match simply because our elevator’s time to goal is only 0.7sec instead of 0.5sec, I’m a happy guy. We got other things to spend time on.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:56:20.015Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":220.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Justin Tervay","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":13}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19731,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/15","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":13}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":13,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681282,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T19:58:52.940Z","cooked":"
kegancherry:

To me it seems like there would have to be thousands of variables for these kind of tools to be truly accurate.

Not really. DC motors are very predictable, very linear systems.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T19:58:52.940Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":54.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/16","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681285,"name":"Kegan Cherry","username":"kegancherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T20:11:43.281Z","cooked":"

Whats the scalability on this? For example last year I solo programmed and tested our robot. We were in such a time crunch that it seems infeasible to do all of this simulation. In other words, when is it sensible to dedicate time to simulate rather than run empirically team wise?

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T20:11:43.281Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kegan Cherry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/17","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681293,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T20:18:42.732Z","cooked":"

You have to have the simulation stack ready before the season, as it can take months to make it well. The slow and hard part is designing the simulator in the first place and knowing how to use it. Once you already have the sim, using it and getting good results takes only minutes.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T20:18:42.732Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":28.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":73648,"username":"kegancherry","name":"Kegan Cherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/18","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681330,"name":"Kabir","username":"kn4","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kn4/{size}/235296_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T21:30:44.761Z","cooked":"

You should think about what goals you need to achieve while tuning. These probably include that your mechanism gets to its position quickly and accurately, and also that you’re not taking up too much time tuning the mechanism.

If just using PositionVoltage and kP/kD works for you and achieves these goals, then you could just continue using it. Personally I’ve seen that using Motion Magic allows for a lot more leeway in your feedback gains (P and D) so you don’t have to spend as much time finding exact values. Some teams just use Motion Magic with only kV and kP (2910 CAD and Tech Binder Release 2025 - #237 by PatrickW). I’ve heard from another team that Motion Magic Expo made their elevator faster after switching to it from PositionVoltage control, but I haven’t tried it myself.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T21:30:44.761Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":22.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504253,"topic_slug":"empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach","display_username":"Kabir","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2910-cad-and-tech-binder-release-2025/500310/237","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"2910 CAD and Tech Binder Release 2025","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":73648,"username":"kegancherry","name":"Kegan Cherry","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kegancherry/{size}/266518_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57470,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2724 programmer"},"post_url":"/t/empirical-tuning-vs-calculating-constants-whats-your-approach/504253/19","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681333,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T21:37:26.002Z","cooked":"

Lots of good technical opinions here, I don’t think I’d have much to add.

Where I throw my “mentor” hat on is to think through team goals overall - do you just need your mechanism to work somewhat well, so that you can move on to other goals? Or does your team value the time and effort to deep-dive the underlying reason ‘why’ something works?

I’d generally argue guess-and-check takes longer to get robust, but doesn’t incur any up-front time to build an accurate software simulation, have accurate weights in CAD, make sure units are right up and down the stack, etc. But, if you change pretty much anything, you’ll likely have to repeat the whole tuning process. Calculated gains are just the opposite: Faster retune cycle, at the cost of more initial setup and design discipline.

Time is your most limited resource. Talk with your team how and where to spend your time for stuff like this - it might have some influence on which technical path you take.
